notes:
1. Ideal Gas Assumptions

An ideal gas is a theoretical gas composed of a set of randomly moving point particles that obey the following assumptions:

  • The volume of the gas molecules themselves is negligible compared to the volume of the container.
  • There are no intermolecular forces (attraction or repulsion) between the gas molecules.
  • Collisions between molecules and the container walls are perfectly elastic.

Real gases behave like ideal gases at high temperatures and low pressures.

2. Equation of State

The Ideal Gas Law relates the absolute pressure ($P$), volume ($V$), and absolute temperature ($T$) of a gas.

$$ Pv = RT $$

where:

  • $P$ = Absolute pressure (Pa or psfa)
  • $v$ = Specific volume ($1/\rho$) (m³/kg or ft³/lb)
  • $T$ = Absolute temperature (K or °R)
  • $R$ = Specific gas constant = $R_u / M$

Alternative forms:

$$ P = \rho RT $$ $$ PV = mRT $$ $$ PV = nR_u T $$
  • $R_u$ = Universal Gas Constant $\approx 8.314$ kJ/kmol·K
  • $n$ = Number of moles
  • $M$ = Molar mass

solvedExamples.question: Under what conditions does a real gas behave most like an ideal gas?
solvedExamples.explanation: At low pressures, gas molecules are far apart, making their volume negligible. At high temperatures, they have high kinetic energy, making intermolecular forces negligible. These conditions satisfy the ideal gas assumptions.

solvedExamples.question: Calculate the specific volume of air at a pressure of 200 kPa and a temperature of 300 K. The specific gas constant for air is $R = 0.287$ kJ/kg·K.
solvedExamples.explanation: Use the ideal gas law: $Pv = RT \implies v = RT/P$. Ensure consistent units (kPa and kJ match). $v = (0.287 \text{ kJ/kg·K})(300 \text{ K}) / 200 \text{ kPa} = 86.1 / 200 = 0.4305$ m³/kg.
